content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun, simple clash that shouldn't be too difficult for most clashers.

Nice clash, easy to solve in 5 minutes.

Only thing stopping me from approving is the statement isn't very clear and the example is too simple to help. The bit where you say "( = 1, ) = 0" is hard to understand because brackets are hard to parse. It would be good to add a larger example in the statement like:

E.g. (()( is 1101 or 13.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a great idea and presents a fun challenge
It's a great concept and a fun challenge!

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hi, good clash. But your solution is complicated to understand, here is a code that i made and which validated all the tests:

a = input().replace('(', '1').replace(')', '0')
b = input().replace('(', '1').replace(')', '0')
print(
    bin( int(a, 2) + int(b, 2) )[2:].replace('1', '(').replace('0', ')')
)

Also, there is no test associated with the INVALID that you put in your solution

Fun!
92 is my best so far

Goal section
* Please explain how 0 and 1 are represented.

Input/Output sections
* Please include line numbers and variable type, and also apply formatting, i.e.
<<Line 1>>: A string [[A]]: The first number

(similar changes for [[B]] and [[C]])

Constraints section
* Please change "len" to "length".

* Please include the lower limit of lengths of A and B.

* Please format A and B as [[variables]].

Thanks.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I like this contribution.
Regarding reverse mode, I'd love to see this exercise (I'm a binary guy), but I reckon this would be out of reach for most people.

Do not bother with INVALID cases, your problem is already complicated enough for a lot of people.
Didn't reallt get the goal
Note that this could also be solved without converting into integers, but I think the solution shown mirrors what more users are likely to do.
Do you think it's too hard to be reverse, or does it just not make sense at all? Or do you not think it's an interesting challenge?
Thanks this is useful! I'll switch to non-reverse modes only and remove the invalid case.
Thank you, I think I've made all the changes you asked for.
Thanks for the concise solution! Yeah I got rid of that test case...
This is a good idea, thank you!

Thank you, please also do the following formatting:

Goal section
* Please format "(", ")", "1" and "0" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

Output section
* Please format "A" and "B" as [[variables]].

Thanks again.
Got it!
